div.p: 17. III:30— Sunday—

St. Patrick’s day— Effigy hanging on Poplar Tree, in front of South window— Heard a Stranger, at the Presbyterian Church 2. Timothy 1–12. [“]For I know whom I have believed; and I am persuaded that he is able to keep that which I have committed unto him against that day.” After dinner at St. John’s Church—Mr Hawley—5th. Sunday in Lent. Text from Psalm 103.17. [“]But the mercy of the Lord is from everlasting to everlasting upon them that fear him, and his righteousness unto children’s children.” My Catarrhal cough racking— My wife’s worse— The children both afflicted with the same—
18. III:45. Monday

Almost sleepless Night. W. Cammack here—executed with him the Agreement of Lease of the lot on G. Street behind the Stable of the house in F. Street where we live. Mary attested it— Call at the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions—gave him papers relating to Margaretta Duffield’s claim for increase of Pension— Also a Letter from Lewis and Pierce of Brooklyn, L.I. containing a pension for widows in Plymouth County, Massachusetts, all but one, mentioned in Jacob H. Loud’s Letter of the 7th. instt. to me— The Sun at Summer heat compelled me to shorten my morning walk— I am still reading Mr Wilcox’s Dissertation upon Slavery and abolition— And a Report to the Senate of New-York, Chairman of a Select Committee, against the abolitionists and the right of Petition; which I received last Night from I know not whom— Evening at whist—
19. IV. Tuesday.

Catarrh still oppressive— Mary Louisa sick in bed. I continue my random Lecture without knowing where it will end— Received from Gales and Seaton, Wheeler’s report of my Speech of 2 March. Took it back to the Office of the National Intelligencer Office Bacon’s Essay on Dispatch— Mi venga la muerte di spagna. Thunder Shower—prevented me from going to the Capitol Library— Mr Reinhart was here with a proposal from a Clerk whom he did not name, to purchase the house that I bought of Mr Daniel Baker— Asked my terms and said he would see me again in two or three days— Afternoon walk round the President’s Square— Mr. John Connell was here this Evening— From Philadelphia this morning, and to leave the City to return thither tomorrow Evening.— I read some pages more of Mr Wilcox’s Chapter 4. appeal to the Union on Abolition, and Slavery, and I received from General Gaines a pamphlet containing sundry Dissertations of his upon the military defences of the United States; with a prefatory Address to the young men of the United States on Steam-frigates.
20— IV:30— Wednesday

Catarrh oppressive— Call at the Pension Office to enquire of Mr Edwards concerning the Pension claim of Mrs Abigail Lincoln recommended to me, by a Letter from Mr James C. Doane of Cohasset, and also from whom the claim of Mrs Lucy Washburn had been received, in whose favour he had sent me a pension Certificate— It was from Mr Jacob H Loud.— Call on Mr Frye to mention the application I had received through Mr Reinhart, to purchase the House which was Daniel Baker’s— At Mr T. B. Johnson’s and delivered to him a Letter from my Son— While I was there Mr Elisha Whittlesey the former member of the House from Ohio called to see me not knowing that I had removed— He is here on private business, and left me to call on M. St. Clair Clarke— I took a second walk after dinner— In the Evening Mr. Reinhart called with Mr Morsell the person who wishes to purchase my house— We agreed upon terms, subject to the final decision of Mr Morsell who will call upon me again in two or three days— Children both sick.
21. V. Thursday

My morning labour employs me from my rising hour till past noon with the interval of breakfast, and an hour to pore over the National Intelligencer of the Morning—while my Catarrhal cough wastes at once my strength and my Spirits, and unfits me for composition— My wife has the same cough, and both the children are confined with it to the chamber— I called at the Office of the National Intelligencer with the concluding List of the Petitions presented by me to the House of Representatives at the 3d. Session of the 25th. Congress— I met there Mr William Cost Johnson member of the late House from Maryland— I went also to the Library at the Capitol, and looked into the Volume of Smith’s Wealth of Nations which I had wanted to consult— Took another walk after dinner— Mr Reinhart was here with a proposal to purchase the house next door to Mr Carbery’s, which I gave some years ago to my wife— But it is now under a lease for four years. Dr Thomas was here to visit the children—and Mr Wilcox who came for his manuscript, but I was not at home. I afterwards met him in the Street, and he promised to call upon me again to-morrow— I took an imagination to look for the celestial armour of AEneas in the 8th. Book of the AEneid, and read it in the original and in Dryden’s translation— The print was so small that I could scarcely read either.
22. IV:30 Friday.

Finished my second Lecture, and began upon the third— Mr Morsell came and informed me that he had concluded to take my House that was Daniel Baker’s; upon the terms that I had proposed— I will not withdraw my consent to them; but on reflection I find them very inconsiderate on my part— Called at the Office of the National Intelligencer, and added to the list of Petitions, received since the close of the Session the three fromreceived last Night— After dinner I took another walk round the President’s Square— I finished reading Mr Wilcox’s Essay upon Slavery and Abolition, and he came and took back his manuscript— There is much reflection, and much incongruity in his work.— His conclusions are all favourable to Colonization; and he proposes to give his manuscript to that Society for publication— I have no faith in Colonization or the Colonization Society. Mr T. B. Johnson was here this morning. The children are still confined to the chamber—
23. IV:45. Saturday

I have determined to accept the invitation of the New-York Historical Society, to deliver, if I possibly can, an address before them on the 30th. of next Month, the 50th. Anniversary of the inauguration of George Washington, as first President of the United States— I have brought myself to this conclusion with extreme repugnance, and under a sense of obligation to that Society which I cannot repress— The subject is rugged with insurmountable difficulties— My reputation, my age, my decaying faculties have all warned me to decline the task— Yet I cannot resist the pressing and repeated invitations of the Society. The day was a real epocha in our history; but to seize and present in bold relief all its peculiar characters would require a younger hand, and a brighter mind— Mr Morsell sent here for the draught of the agreement between us which I had promised to make— It was not ready, but I finished it afterwards— Walk before dinner to the Capitol Library, and after dinner round the President’s Square. The Children still confined to the chamber. answered Blunt’s Letter of invitation from the New-York Historical Society; and received a second from him requesting an answer.
24. V. Sunday

Presbyterian Church. Heard Mr Fowler, from Romans 8.8. [“]So then they that are in the flesh, cannot please God.” Calvinistic to the core— The virtues of the unregenerate are no better than their vices— They cannot please God— Mrs Smith and Mary dined at Mr T. B. Johnson’s— Afternoon at St John’s Church. Mr Hawley read prayers for the Sunday before Easter—and gave notice that there would be service at the Church next Wednesday and Friday mornings— Short discourse from Proverbs 21.25. [“]The desire of the slothful killeth him; for his hands refuse to labour.”—upon religious industry. I gave much of the leisure of this day, to a search in Hume’s History for the account of the Petition of Right in 1628
25. V:15. Monday

Called on the Secretary of the Treasury at his Office in the new Treasury building, with a Letter from George L. Phillips at St. Augustine, praying for the appointment of his Son John Lott Phillips to be Surveyor of that Port; an office which he supposed to be vacant. Mr Woodbury told me that he had received also a Letter from the same person—but he was mistaken— The Office of the Surveyor of the Port was not vacant; but that of a supervisor, to which the appointment belonged to the Collector.— I spoke to Mr Woodbury also of the Smithsonian fund— Told him what had been done with relation to it in Congress, and what had not been done— How the two Messages of the President on the subject had been referred to a select Committee of 9 of which I had been Chairman— How Asher Robbins a Senator from Rhode Island, being laid politically on the shelf by his Constituents had taken a fancy to this fund, for the comfort and support of his old age, and projected an University of which he was to be the Rector Magnificus— So he made an elegant Literary Speech in the Senate and moved for a joint Committee 7. from the Senate— The House concurred and the Speaker appointed the same Committee of 9 that he had appointed before to join the Committee of the Senate. There were several meetings of the joint Committee—scarcely ever a quorum of the Senate’s Committee; but they gave carte blanche to their Chairman— He prepared his Bill for 9 Trustees three chosen by each House, and 3 by the President, to sit during the recess and prepare a plan to be submitted to Congress at the next Session for a Corporation of which the same Trustees were to form a part— I had offered Resolutions against all this which the Committee of the House adopted and I prepared a Bill conformably to my own plan. By way of compromise it was agreed that both Committees Should report both Bills which was done.— I never called either of them up in the House, for I knew it would be in vain— Robbins attempted to get up his Bill in the Senate, but could not carry it through— I left copies of both Bills of my Resolutions and of Robbins’s propositions with Mr Woodbury requesting him to consider them, and inviting his views concerning them—telling him that I should if able to take my Seat at the next Session of Congress resume the subject, in which I felt an interest more intense than in any thing else before that body.— I told him that before leaving this place, I intended to see and speak again with the President concerning it. Mr Woodbury promised to give his attention to the subject, and to speak of it also to the President. But he told me that in the general appropriation Bill 10000 dollars had been taken from this fund to pay for the expenses and charges of procuring the money. Cambreleng swindled this into the Bill without my knowledge; and it crept
crept through both Houses unobserved. I shamed him out of it last year, and I believe he did it now to spite me— The Attorney General had given an opinion against it— I am deeply mortified not to have detected this dirty trick. I called at the Pension Office; with a Letter from Mr William Ellis at Dedham concerning a Pension claim of Lydia Rhoades, and upon a question concerning a Pension claim by a Privateersman.— They have no claim— At the Office of the National Intelligencer— Seaton gave me some papers, and shewed me an Epistle from F. Hassler concerning the frontier at Rouse’s point somewhat waspish— After dinner I took a second walk— Mr Reinhart was here about the houses—but thought the lot was so much smaller, than Mr Morsell had expected, that he might wish to revoke the bargain, which I told him he should be welcome to do— I wrote to Lewis and Pierce to Jacob H. Loud, and to James C. Doane, with enclosures to them all.
26. V:15 Tuesday

Continuing the view of the origin and progress of the confederacy, and feel the necessity of measuring the terms in which I am to discourse. It is difficult to tread with decorum a political doctrine in which there is moral obliquity— Such I deem the pretension of a State Sovereignty, having power to annul its own contract, which is but another form of the papal creed that Faith is not to be kept with heretics. State Sovereignty is but another name for knavery, and the right of bilking its own engagements is fitter for discussion among the convicts of the penitentiary than in an assembly of honest and honourable men— But the suspension of specie payments by the Banks is precisely of the same character— Mr Morsell was here and I gave him my draught of an agreement for the purchase and sale of my house on Square 214.— He said there was more ground enclosed round the house than appeared on my Deed; but I said I could convey no more than my deed contained; and that if he wished to reconsider the agreement, I would not hold him to his bargain— I walked to the Capitol and selected several Documents for Dr J. W. Webster— Met in the Library judge Baldwin and Dr Sewall— Latin inscription on the pedestal of the bust of Thomas Jefferson—Summo rerum Moderatori—To the Ruler of the Universe— Judge Baldwin asked for a translation of it— I spoke to Dr Sewall about his two Lectures on Phrenology—of which a new Edition is about to be published, and of which he has written to request of me a recommendation— I read several Chapters of Judge Story’s Commentaries on the Constitution of the United States Particularly his remarks on the Articles of Confederation— Mrs Smith dined abroad— The children yesterday and this morning resumed their Bible reading with me— Second walk in the Evening twilight— Received a Letter from Robert Gilmor at Baltimore about the Washington column and one from Jesse Perkins of North Bridgewater concerning the Pension claim of Polly Tillson. Death of Lemuel Spear at Boston last Wednesday—
27. V Wednesday

Continuing the review of the Articles of Confederation, and the contrast of their principles with those of the Declaration of Independence; a contrast which strikes me more forcibly the more thoroughly I examine the facts—but how shall I escape making it tedious and uninteresting, especially as I have twice or three times broached and partially exposed my views of the subject— Hours and hours of this day were consumed in turn over the History of the Confederation and the Journals of the Revolutionary and Confederation Congress— Walk before dinner, half way to the College hill.— Summer weather— No fire in my chamber— Walk again in Evening twilight to the Louisiana Avenue— Letter to Dr J. W. Webster with a packet of Congressional Documents which he had requested— Letter from W. S Cruft of New-York requesting Documents, and one from J L. Edwards, concerning the Pension claim for Daniel Rhodes— My Catarrhal cough has partially subsided, and I occupy the whole day— Conjunction of the Moon and Mars
28. V. Thursday

Still prosing upon the Confederation and the Convention that formed the Constitution of the United States— Mr Richard I Morsell came with his Son and Mr R. D. Beale, and we executed the agreement for the sale of my house which I purchased of Daniel Baker— I walked to the Capitol and applied at the Document room for 3 copies of Mr Buchanans report made to the Senate last July upon the North eastern boundary dispute; but they were not to be found. In the library I consulted the 2d. volume of the last Edition of Marshall’s life of Washington for authority that the first project of a Convention to revise the Articles of Confederation was broached at Mount Vernon in March 1785. which I found— I rumaged over also the first volume of Sparks’s diplomatic correspondence for the first appointment of Consuls to France during the revolutionary War— There is a bust of Mr Jefferson by Ceracchi over a fluted column of Egyptian marble, black, upon a curious pedestal of white marble upon which there is a Latin inscription in honour of Jefferson himself— Meehan told me that the Pedestal had been a present from Madame de Tessé, and that there had been a vase upon it—but that he had bought the Egyptian column of black marble and had paid Ceracchi 700 dollars for the bust— There was also a Medallion of Mr Madison by Ceracchi a very poor likeness of him, when he was young and now placed by Mrs Madison there for safe keeping— I took a second walk after Sunset and came home, very much fatigued, and maimed for the labour of writing or reading—
29. V. Friday.

Good Friday— Summer heat—excessive languor and affliction—but yet writing 3 pages every day for the historical disquisition to be read to the New-York historical Society on the 30th. of next Month. I have written
written matter for an hour and a half’s reading, and am not yet upon the threshold of my subject— When I come to it, I fear I shall be as brief, as I have been hitherto excursive— I do not yet perceive the point of view from which it may be presented in the most comprehensive and most interesting light— I called at Mr Frye’s Office, and requested him to give notice to Mr Wilkins the tenant of the House in Square 214. that possession must be given to Mr Morsell next Monday— I thought Mr Frye had told me that Wilkins himself had given notice that he would then quit; but Mr Frye now says that he only talked about quitting to get his rent reduced. He said also that Wilkins’s month would run till the 5th. of next month— At the Pension Office— I desired Mr Edwards to make out the Pension certificate for Lydia Rhodes, for the amount of service of her deceased husband which he considers as proved, so that she may be sure of that, and take her chance for any additional Service which she may hereafter be able to prove— I left with him also Mr Jesse Perkins’s Letter concerning the pension claim of Polly Tillson, and I enquired for Mr Ramsdell methodist preacher at Pembroke, whether the families, of Officers or Soldiers, who died of fevers in the last War with england, were entitled to pensions— They are not— At the third Auditor’s Office to enquire concerning the pensions of the family of a person named Cobb— Mr Hagner told me the certificates were transmitted to them on the 19th instt. My wife and Mary went to St. John’s Church for the morning service— Mrs Smith dined abroad— My wife and Mary spent the Evening at Mrs Hellen’s Second walk by twilight.
30. V. Saturday.

Rainy morning, and then cleared away cold.— Mr work grows heavier and more tedious as I advance; and my subject like a Spectre, recedes as I approach it— I consume every day more time in filling up my task of three pages—and seriously apprehend coming to a stand before I get through. Mr Charles a young Painter of this place came with a Letter of recommendation from Mr Gales, and asked me to sit to him for my picture which I promised to do next Monday— Morning walk to the Office of the National Intelligencer, where Seaton gave me some Boston Newspapers, and told me of a Report that the Duke of Wellington has been disabled by a shock of Apoplexy or of Palsy— Second walk after Sunset— Short— I read some pages of George A. Otis’s translation of the first of Cicero’s Tusculan disputations, upon death; and I wanted to see the passage in the Offices which describes the love of Country— Borrowed of W. S. Smith Barrett’s French Translation, and found the passage; but have not yet got it in the original— Letters from the Commissioner of Pensions, from Lewis and Pierce, and from W. C. Rogers and Co. at Gonaives with a Copy of the Constitution of Haïti! [symbols]
31. V:15. Sunday

Easter.— Heard at the Presbyterian Church Mr Fowler, from Ephesians 2:12—“Having no Hope”—a small part of the verse— The desperate condition of the unconverted— He repeated the words “having no hope[”] so often and with such a growing prolongation of emphasis upon the negative particle that it bordered upon the burlesque—and the good man asked if some of us his impenitent friends did not feel ourselves in that condition? But for the indecency of interrupting him I was tempted to answer No!—how is it with you? After dinner I went to St. John’s Church at the usual hour of half past 3. but found in the Church only two boys, one of whom said that the service has been this day postponed to an hour later— I returned home and went again at half past 4— Mr Hawley read the Evening service for Easter day, and preached from Isaiah 44.9. [“]They that make a graven image are all of them vanity: and their delectable things shall not profit: and they are their own witnesses; they see not, nor know; that they may be ashamed.” Upon the idolatry of graven images— I took both the children to Church with me Morning and afternoon— Mrs Thornton spent the Evening here—

Day— Since the close of the Session of Congress, Monday Morning 4. March between 2 and 3. O’Clock, after taking two days to recruit my strength exhausted by Sittings day and night for the preceding week, I have risen between 4 and 5. every morning and employed myself in writing till noon or 1. P.M— Then walked abroad for two or three hours to the Capitol, or to the National Intelligencer Office. Dine between 3 and 4— Return to my chamber till evening twilight— Then walk again half an hour. Cup of warm milk and water instead of tea which I cannot drink— Evening with my family or in my chamber reading Letters or Newspapers brought by the Mail—or writing till between 10 and 11 when I retire to bed.— Immediately after the close of the Session of Congress I took a racking Catarrhal Cough, from which I am not yet entirely relieved though much better— My wife and both the children have suffered the same affliction, but are recovering.— I am labouring much in mind, but more in Spirits, upon an undertaking rashly assumed to deliver on the 30th of April a Discourse before the New-York Historical Society— [symbols]
